content: The Indian Health Care Improvement Technical Corrections Act of 1996, also known as the Indian Health Care Improvement Act, makes technical corrections to the Indian Health Care Improvement Act. The Indian Health Care Improvement Act is amended to include allopathic medicine and allied health professions. Indian Health Professions Scholarships now require recipients to fulfill their service obligation in full-time practice. The Act further states that upon the death of an individual who receives an Indian Health Scholarship, any obligation for service or payment related to the scholarship shall be canceled. The Secretary has the authority to waive or suspend obligations of service or payment if it is not possible for the recipient to meet them or if doing so would result in extreme hardship. The Secretary may waive the right of the United States to recover funds in cases of extreme hardship or for good cause shown. Obligations for payment under an Indian Health Scholarship cannot be discharged in bankruptcy unless granted after a 5-year period and if the court finds it unconscionable.
